title: Dose Response Curve Model
drEquation: Choose a dose response equation from the dropdown. The default is LL.4 (a four-parameter Log-logistic model)
drDataType: If needed, choose from the dropdown based on the data type being analyzed
ED: Estimation of effective dose response. The default is 50%. You can specify more than one level (e.g. 10, 50, 90)
curveid: A variable if contains the grouping of the data
weights: A variable used as weight (Y) with a power value
PowerKweight: Power: for just Y, choose (-1), for 1/Y, choose 1, 1/(Y^2), choose 2, .. 1/(Y^5), choose 5,..
resNormalityTestChk: Normality test of the model residuals
modelConstraintLabel: (Optional) Various Model constraints for parameter estimations
pmodels: Set starting values for parameters to guide model optimization/convergence e.g. LL.4 data.frame(Herbicide,1,1,Herbicide) or LL.3 list(~group, ~1, ~group)
paramConstraints: Fix one or more of the parameters to constant values e.g. NA, 0.5, NA to set upper limit fixed at 0.5 for LL.3, a three parameter function
paramConstraintsLower: Set the constraint for lower limit e.g. Brain-Cousens model BC.5 with the constraint b>3 as (3, -Inf, -Inf, -Inf, -Inf)
paramConstraintsUpper: Set the constraint for upper limit e.g. Log Logistic LL.4 with the constraint as (3, Inf, Inf, 2)
logScaleAxis: X axis is plotted in log scale by default. Choose the empty option from the dropdown to plot in original scale
EDpointValueChk: Plot the values next to ED points on the plot
doseInLogScaleChk: Check if the dose/concentration is already in logarithmic values in the dataset
ModelSelectTestChk: Perform model fit test to compare with one or more models
modelSelectTest: Select  (click/un-click)  one or more models to compare fit

help.title: Dose Response Curve Model (DRC)
help.body:
Description
Analysis of dose-response data through a suite of flexible and versatile model fitting and after-fitting analysis functions to estimate parameters with the various dose response equation function

Parameter names when present in the DRC model depending on the dose response equation function chosen from the dropdown list
Slope (b)
Lower Asymptote (c)
Upper Asymptote (d)
ED50 (e)
Extra Slope (f)

For a mm.2 or mm.3 model (Michaelis-Menten Model with 2 or 3 Parameters)
Vmax (d) maximum reaction rate
Km (e) Michaelis constant
h (c) Hill coefficient

Check the following R pages for details
help(package ='drc')
help(drm, package ='drc')
help(getMeanFunctions, package ='drc')

A few great reference materials in addition to the R help(drm, package ='drc')

Five illustrative examples of dose-response modelling
https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0146021.s001

Draft manual for Dose response curves in R written by the authors of the DRC package
https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Alan-Reynolds-4/post/dose_response_curves_is_better_to_create_different_models_or_just_one/attachment/59d63b8c79197b8077998961/AS%3A411294889988097%401475071751844/download/DraftDrcManual.pdf

Complete online manual for the DRC package https://rdrr.io/cran/drc/man/

You can try this dialog

Example 1
Load dataset S.alba from Load Datasets menu (choose drc as package)
Choose (drag) DryMatter as response variable
Choose (drag) Dose as dose variable and (optionally) Herbicide to grouping data field
Also optionally check/click "Perform model fit test to compare with one or more models" to compare a few alternate models for the fit

Example 2
Load dataset earthworms from Load Datasets menu (choose drc as package)
Choose (drag) number and then drag total into the response field. Hand type / to create expression as number/total in the response field
Choose (drag) dose as dose variable
Choose from the drop down "Choose a dose response equation.." LL.3 instead of the default LL.4
Choose from the drop down binomial instead of the default empty value
Type in 50,10, 90 in the Estimation of effective dose response filed to see the dose response for 10%, 50%, 90% on the model plot
Leave everything else as default in the dialog. Execute the dialog

Description of the dose response equation functions available in the dropdown list

Log-logistic (ED50 as parameter) with lower limit at 0 and upper limit at 1 (2 parameters) LL.2

Log-logistic (ED50 as parameter) with lower limit at 0 (3 parameters) LL.3

Log-logistic (ED50 as parameter) with upper limit at 1 (3 parameters) LL.3u

Log-logistic (ED50 as parameter) (4 parameters) LL.4

Generalized log-logistic (ED50 as parameter) (5 parameters) LL.5

Weibull (type 1) with lower limit at 0 and upper limit at 1 (2 parameters) W1.2

Weibull (type 1) with lower limit at 0 (3 parameters) W1.3

Weibull (type 1) (4 parameters) W1.4

Weibull (type 2) with lower limit at 0 and upper limit at 1 (2 parameters) W2.2

Weibull (type 2) with lower limit at 0 (3 parameters) W2.3

Weibull (type 2) (4 parameters) W2.4

Brain-Cousens (hormesis) with lower limit fixed at 0 (4 parameters) BC.4

Brain-Cousens (hormesis) (5 parameters) BC.5

Log-logistic (log(ED50) as parameter) with lower limit at 0 and upper limit at 1 (2 parameters) LL2.2

Log-logistic (log(ED50) as parameter) with lower limit at 0 (3 parameters) LL2.3

Log-logistic (log(ED50) as parameter) with upper limit at 1 (3 parameters) LL2.3u

Log-logistic (log(ED50) as parameter) (4 parameters) LL2.4

Generalised log-logistic (log(ED50) as parameter) (5 parameters) LL2.5

Asymptotic regression with lower limit at 0 (2 parameters) AR.2

Shifted asymptotic regression (3 parameters) AR.3

Michaelis-Menten (2 parameters) MM.2

Shifted Michaelis-Menten (3 parameters) MM.3

Exponential (2 parameters) EXD.2 (AR.2 can be used too)

Exponential (3 parameters) EXD.3 (AR.3 can be used too)

Exponential (3 parameters) EXD.3 (AR.3 can be used too)
